Problem:
Consider a control system in which an input vector \\( u(t) \\) influences the output \\( x(t) \\) via the differential equation \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + Bu \\), where A and B are constant matrices. We investigate the change induced by a transformation defined by the function \\( h(x) = Ce^{Dt}x \\) where C and D are also constant matrices.

If \\( h(x) \\) is applied to the state \\( x_0 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + Bu \\) without any further intervention, will the state \\( x(T) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( x_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + Bu \\)?
Explanation: The application of \\( h(x) \\) alters the initial state in a manner affected by C and D. This change can significantly alter the dynamics governed by A and B, resulting in a different trajectory and ending state at time T.

causal_map_integration: The input vector u(t) directly influences the output x(t). The state x(t) transforms into h(x) via the function h(x) = Ce^{Dt}x. The initial state x_0 evolves to x(t) under the control system dynamics. The transformed state h(x_0) also influences the state x(t). The final state x(T) is derived from the state x(t) at time T.
